content:
Why you say "resulting_height" for the number of folds in output section? this is very confusing.
Why did people approve this without even reading it...
EDIT: I edited the statement and replaced "resulting_height" with "fold_count"

>When we fold only in one axis, length of our paper will remain unchanged
Length and axis aren't even used in the puzzle, why mention them?

>unit measurement
I keep seeing this but I'm not sure if this is really necessary in CoC puzzles unless conversion is involved. Can't we just say "thickness of T" instead of "T m"? I'm open to discussion on this one, as it became a standard in many puzzles

Also, sentences related to goal are scattered everywhere. You almost created a new paragraph for every single sentence. Group your sentences to small amount of paragraphs and group those paragraphs with the logic they relate to. For instance: Start with a paragraph that tells about the rules. Then create a new paragraph about the goal. Man, I've lost at least 1-2 mins while solving the puzzle because of how disorganized the statement was

I've upvoted it because I like the theme but can't approve it at this state of the statement
I agree with previous comments about rephrasing the input. I would also stay with meters instead of millimeters. After those fixes I will be happy to accept :)
Doesn't fit too well the current trend of "clashes must be hard"

You need to rewrite a lot of this, a lot of lines are pretty confusing.

A space separated values -> 3

In a separate lines write the following integer results: -> in 2
Is there a reason <<T>> has to stay in millimetres? For the sake of the CoC, how about we just normalize everything to meters instead? 4m/100m/12m => 5 folds and 384m needed in width?

I like the statement. Not too simple, not to hard, just fine.
I just see the following problems :
  - "Basically, by folding a piece of paper in half, we make it higher." -> The information that the height is doubled with each fold is not clear enough (even if logical)
  - In the statement, the expectations are not clear enough. A final sentence to describe what is expected will not be too much (ex: "The goal here is to compute the number of folds required, and the required width of the unfolded piece of paper")
  - The text in the 'output' category is not formated as usual. A nominal and short sentence per variable help for the readibility.
If this get fix, I'll probably approve this CoC. :)
I didn't see the millimeters and meters thing at first, which made me very confused. It might work better if you use meters for T, since that'll keep all your units the same.

Two issues came to me when I tried to do this puzzle:

1) How can we calculate the amount of paper necessary when we don't know the target thickness of the bridge? All we're given is the length and width... so can't that just be the answer and 1 fold under the given constraints?

2) You can actually be folding this on any of the x/y/z axis, and it will change the number of folds obviously that are expected. (are you looking at the bridge from a top view, sideways, or from on end looking on towards the other, as you're folding the paper?). Clarification here is necessary imo.

I should rather specify that you need to only calculate the width of the sheet. There is also an annotation that we fold the same way all the time without rotating etc., I can add that it means we do not switch folding axis
Also, millimeters is spelled incorrectly, and there are a few other grammatical mistakes :P
Shoutout to the Shortest clash with solution in Perl `print<>*32`
I changed the description, what do you think about it now?
To be fair, that one is literally the oldest clash on the site.

I'm not really referring to switching axis -> moreso I'm talking about the starting axis. Are we folding it (looking at the bridge from a birds eye view, the bridge going E/W along the X axis)  in a way that every fold makes the x, y, or z axis grow? I assume z, but the other directions are totally valid.

Additionally as I mentioned, I don't yet see the constraint on why we can't just answer width = minimum width every time. Since we're not answering length it can be assumed that the paper has the same w/l ratio, and there is no demanded thickness for the paper.

Imagine a sheet of length x and width y. When you fold it in half, around the vertical axis, width is reduced, but length stays the same. When you repeat the process, length still stays the same,

And the length of the bridge is the thickness of the folded paper. Not the thickness of a single unfolded sheet.

Alright, with that clarification I was able to solve the puzzle.

Personally I got really hung up on the imagery and it was a difficult one to understand, for the purposes of a clash puzzle. If others express the same issue, I'd look at having the same problem but just in a different context (like -> making a stack of paper at least X high) could clear up a lot of the axis confusions and actually get to the point quicker on what the puzzle is asking for, which is important for a clash puzzle :)

Darn, I didn't think of it that way.

I changed the description, it should be clearer now
